On my stories - again, I can only speak from when I was working with the tabloids.

They had to sign contracts.
We had to have extra documentation, photographs to support their claims, because if what they were saying was false, the tabloids would go down.

Was the job fun?
Yes.
I have to admit it was fun.
I was young, and I was naive, and I loved the adrenaline involved, and I loved walking into the office and not knowing where I was going to be or what celebrity I was going to have to be following.
And one day, I walked into the office and my editor said, Marlise, is your passport in order?

And next thing I knew, I was flying off to Cairo to follow a celebrity, or I'd head off to London, or just be on planes all over the United States.

I couldn't justify what I was doing anymore.
There eventually came a point where I was asked to write a headline involving a photo that I could tell that the photo had been doctored.

And at that point, a lot of the competition was gone as well.
In 1999, David Pecker came along and he bought American Media.
And he bought out the National Enquirer and Star and Globe.
